title: How to Make Crème Brulée

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 325º F (163º C).
Prepare the vanilla pods.
steps.description: Using the knife, slice down the middle of the pods and split them open. Scrape out the pulp onto a clean surface and keep the leftover pods.

steps.headline: Add the cream, vanilla pulp, and vanilla pods to a medium saucepan set on medium high.
Heat the cream and vanilla mixture until it just begins to boil, or until soft bubbles begin forming at the sides of the saucepan.
steps.description: Once it starts boiling or bubbles start forming, remove the saucepan and its contents from the heat.

steps.headline: Let the cream mixture stand, covered, for  15 minutes.
steps.description: Pick out the vanilla pods when the cream has finished cooling.

steps.headline: While the cream mixture cools, whisk the egg yolks and 1/2 cup of sugar together.
steps.description: Whisk together until the yolks break up completely and the mixture changes to a slightly lighter color.

steps.headline: Slowly incorporate the cream into the yolk mixture, bit by bit, stirring constantly.
steps.description: If you incorporate the cream in too quickly, the eggs may cook. Don't rush this step!

steps.headline: Strain the mixture through a sieve to remove any grit.
Pour cream into six ramekins resting on a high-walled roasting dish.
Pour enough hot water into the tray to reach halfway up the ramekins.
steps.description: This set-up is known as a bain marie.

steps.headline: Place the filled ramekins into the preheated oven and bake for 40 to 45 minutes.
steps.description: When ready, they'll be set on the edges but "jiggly" at the center.

steps.headline: Transfer the ramekins onto a cooling rack.
steps.description: Remove the crèmes brûlées from the oven when baked, and, taking great care as the ramekins will be very hot, transfer them out of the bain marie and onto a cooling rack. Allow them to cool to room temperature.

steps.headline: Refrigerate them for up to 2 hours, covering ramekins in plastic wrap.
Sprinkle the excess sugar over each crème brûlée.
steps.description: Make sure that the sugar coats the crème brûlée evenly. An uneven coat of sugar will make the caramelization harder.

steps.headline: Quickly caramelize the top with the blow torch or a kitchen butane torch.
steps.description: Don't caramelize it for more than roughly 8-10 seconds. If you over-heat it, the sugar will turn black. If you don't have a blowtorch, move the wire rack in the oven to its highest position and turn on the broiler. Set the ramekins on a baking sheet and place them underneath the broiler, twisting the ramekins often for even browning.

steps.headline: Refrigerate for another 45 minutes before serving (optional).
steps.description: Letting them refrigerate for any longer may allow the sugar to dissolve back into the custard. This step is optional, as some prefer to caramelize the sugar immediately before serving.

text: Heating the Cream Preheat the oven to 325º F (163º C).  Prepare the vanilla pods. Using the knife, slice down the middle of the pods and split them open. Scrape out the pulp onto a clean surface and keep the leftover pods. Add the cream, vanilla pulp, and vanilla pods to a medium saucepan set on medium high.  Heat the cream and vanilla mixture until it just begins to boil, or until soft bubbles begin forming at the sides of the saucepan. Once it starts boiling or bubbles start forming, remove the saucepan and its contents from the heat. Let the cream mixture stand, covered, for  15 minutes. Pick out the vanilla pods when the cream has finished cooling. Cooking the Custard While the cream mixture cools, whisk the egg yolks and 1/2 cup of sugar together. Whisk together until the yolks break up completely and the mixture changes to a slightly lighter color. Slowly incorporate the cream into the yolk mixture, bit by bit, stirring constantly. If you incorporate the cream in too quickly, the eggs may cook. Don't rush this step! Strain the mixture through a sieve to remove any grit.  Pour cream into six ramekins resting on a high-walled roasting dish.  Pour enough hot water into the tray to reach halfway up the ramekins. This set-up is known as a bain marie. Place the filled ramekins into the preheated oven and bake for 40 to 45 minutes. When ready, they'll be set on the edges but "jiggly" at the center. Transfer the ramekins onto a cooling rack. Remove the crèmes brûlées from the oven when baked, and, taking great care as the ramekins will be very hot, transfer them out of the bain marie and onto a cooling rack. Allow them to cool to room temperature. Refrigerate them for up to 2 hours, covering ramekins in plastic wrap.  Caramelizing the Top Sprinkle the excess sugar over each crème brûlée. Make sure that the sugar coats the crème brûlée evenly. An uneven coat of sugar will make the caramelization harder. Quickly caramelize the top with the blow torch or a kitchen butane torch. Don't caramelize it for more than roughly 8-10 seconds. If you over-heat it, the sugar will turn black. If you don't have a blowtorch, move the wire rack in the oven to its highest position and turn on the broiler. Set the ramekins on a baking sheet and place them underneath the broiler, twisting the ramekins often for even browning. Refrigerate for another 45 minutes before serving (optional). Letting them refrigerate for any longer may allow the sugar to dissolve back into the custard. This step is optional, as some prefer to caramelize the sugar immediately before serving. Finished.
